name: Liu Wei
bio: Liu Wei is a master chef who has dedicated his life to perfecting the art of Chinese cuisine. With over 20 years of experience, he has created a vast collection of recipes that showcase the diverse flavors and techniques of Chinese cooking.

recipes.name: Kung Pao Chicken
ingredients: 1 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast, cut into bite-sized pieces
recipes.method:
1. In a small bowl, whisk together soy sauce, rice vinegar, sugar, cornstarch, and Sichuan peppercorn.
2. Heat vegetable oil in a large wok or skillet over high heat. Add chicken and stir-fry until golden brown, about 5 minutes.
3. Add peanuts, green onions, garlic, ginger, and red bell pepper to the wok and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes.
4. Pour in the sauce and chicken broth, and stir-fry for another 2-3 minutes, until the sauce has thickened and the chicken is cooked through.
5. Serve hot, over cooked rice.

recipes.name: Hot and Sour Soup
ingredients: 6 dried shiitake mushrooms, soaked in hot water for 30 minutes
recipes.method:
1. Drain the soaked shiitake mushrooms and slice them thinly.
2. In a large pot, bring chicken stock to a boil. Add soy sauce, rice vinegar, and sliced mushrooms.
3. In a small bowl, whisk together cornstarch and 1/4 cup cold water until smooth. Add the cornstarch mixture to the pot and stir well.
4. In a separate pan, heat vegetable oil over medium-high heat. Add ginger, garlic, white pepper, and black pepper, and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes.
5. Add bamboo shoots and tofu to the pot, and stir-fry for another 1-2 minutes. Pour in the beaten eggs while stirring the soup gently to create egg ribbons.
6. Serve hot, garnished

recipes.name: Mapo Tofu
recipes.method:
1. Cut the tofu into small cubes and set aside.
2. In a small bowl, whisk together Sichuan bean paste, chili bean paste, soy sauce, sugar, cornstarch, and chicken broth.
3. Heat vegetable oil in a wok or skillet over high heat. Add ground pork and stir-fry until browned, about 5 minutes.
4. Add green onions, garlic, ginger, and Sichuan peppercorn to the wok and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes.
5. Pour in the sauce and bring to a boil. Add the tofu cubes and gently stir to coat them with the sauce.
6. Cook for another 2-3 minutes, until the sauce has thickened and the tofu is heated through.
7. Serve hot, over cooked rice.

name: Li Ming
bio: Li Ming is a renowned chef specializing in Cantonese cuisine with over 25 years of experience in the industry. Her passion for cooking started at a young age, and she has since mastered the art of blending bold flavors and textures to create unforgettable dishes that delight the senses.

recipes.name: Roast Duck
ingredients: 1 whole duck, cleaned and pat dry
recipes.method:
1. Preheat the oven to 375°F. Combine honey, soy sauce, rice vinegar, five-spice powder, and salt in a small bowl.
2. Brush the mixture over the duck, making sure to coat it evenly.
3. Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add ginger, green onions, and garlic and cook for 1-2 minutes.
4. Add the duck and cook for 5 minutes on each side, until browned.
5. Transfer the duck to a roasting pan and roast in the oven for 1 hour, basting with the remaining marinade every 20 minutes.
6. Remove the duck from the oven and let it rest for 10 minutes before carving and serving.

recipes.name: Shrimp Dumplings
recipes.method:
1. In a food processor, pulse shrimp, bamboo shoots, water chestnuts, soy sauce, sesame oil, cornstarch, vegetable oil, sugar, and white pepper until smooth.
2. Place a tablespoon of the filling in the center of a wonton wrapper. Brush the edges with water and fold the wrapper over the filling to form a half-moon shape. Pinch the edges to seal.
3. Repeat with remaining wrappers and filling.
4. Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add dumplings and cook for 3-4 minutes, until they float to the surface.
5. Serve hot, garnished with chopped green onions.

recipes.name: Steamed Fish
ingredients: Salt and white pepper to taste
recipes.method:
1. Score the fish by making 3-4 diagonal cuts on both sides of the fish. This helps the fish cook evenly and absorb the flavors better.Place the fish on a heat-proof plate that fits inside a steamer basket. Add the ginger, garlic, and green onions on top of the fish.
In a small bowl, mix together the soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, vegetable oil, salt, and white pepper. Pour this mixture evenly over the fish.
Fill a pot or wok with water and bring it to a boil. Place the steamer basket with the fish inside and cover with a lid.
Steam the fish over high heat for 12-15 minutes, depending on the thickness of the fish. Check for doneness by inserting a knife into the thickest part of the fish; if the flesh flakes easily, it is cooked through.
Once the fish is cooked, remove it from the steamer and pour the juices from the plate into a saucepan. Heat the juices over high heat for 1-2 minutes until it comes to a boil.
Pour the hot juices over the fish and garnish with cilantro leaves if desired.
Serve hot with steamed rice and vegetables on the side.

name: Wang Xiaoming
bio: Wang Xiaoming is a skilled Chinese chef who has been passionate about cooking since he was a child. With over 15 years of experience, he has developed a deep understanding of traditional Chinese flavors and techniques, as well as a creative approach to modern fusion cuisine.

recipes.name: Dan Dan Noodles
recipes.method:
1. Cook the noodles according to the package instructions. Drain and set aside.
2. Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium heat. Add the ground pork and stir-fry until cooked through.
3. Add the chili oil, Sichuan peppercorn, soy sauce, black vinegar, and sugar to the wok. Stir-fry for 1-2 minutes until the sauce is fragrant.
4. Add the cooked noodles to the wok and toss to coat with the sauce.
5. Serve hot, garnished with chopped scallions, cilantro, and peanuts.

recipes.name: Shrimp with Garlic Sauce
ingredients: 1 lb. large shrimp, peeled and deveined
recipes.method:
1. In a small bowl, whisk together the cornstarch, Shaoxing wine, soy sauce, and sugar. Set aside.
2. Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Add the shrimp and stir-fry until pink, about 2-3 minutes.
3. Add the minced garlic and ginger to the wok and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
4. Pour in the chicken broth and bring to a boil.
5. Add the cornstarch mixture to the wok and stir well to thicken the sauce.
6. Serve hot, garnished with chopped scallions.

recipes.name: Moo Shu Pork
ingredients: 8 oz. boneless pork loin, thinly sliced
recipes.method: Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet/wok. Stir-fry pork for 2-3 mins, add mushrooms, cabbage, carrots, garlic and green onions. Stir-fry for another 2-3 mins. Pour in beaten eggs and stir-fry for 1 min. Season with salt and white pepper. Serve on a Moo Shu pancake with a dollop of hoisin sauce.

name: Zhang Jie
bio: Zhang Jie is a Chinese chef with a passion for blending traditional techniques with modern flavors. With over 15 years of experience, he has created a diverse range of recipes that showcase the best of Chinese cuisine.

recipes.name: Dumplings
recipes.method:
1. In a large bowl, mix together the ground pork, napa cabbage, green onions, ginger, garlic, soy sauce, sesame oil, sugar, salt, and white pepper.
2. Place a heaping teaspoon of filling in the center of each wonton wrapper. Moisten the edges of the wrapper with water, and fold it in half to form a triangle. Press the edges together to seal.
3. Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add the dumplings, and stir gently to prevent them from sticking together. Cook for 3-4 minutes, or until they float to the surface and are cooked through.
4. Heat the vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the cooked dumplings and fry for 2-3 minutes on each side, until they are golden brown and crispy.
5. Serve hot, with soy sauce or your favorite dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Ma Po Tofu
recipes.method: Brown ground pork in a hot pan, add garlic, ginger and Sichuan peppercorns. Add doubanjiang, fermented black beans, and stir-fry. Add chicken broth and tofu, and let it simmer. Mix cornstarch with water and stir into the mixture. Add green onions, sesame oil, and adjust seasoning to taste. Serve hot with rice.

recipes.name: Steamed Fish with Ginger and Scallionsu
ingredients: 1 whole fish (about 2 lbs), cleaned and scaled
2 inch piece of ginger, peeled and cut into thin strips
recipes.method:
1. Place the fish on a heatproof plate and scatter the ginger and scallions on top,
2. In a small bowl, whisk together the soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, sugar, and sesame oil. Drizzle the mixture over the fish.,
3. Bring a large pot of water to a boil and place a steamer basket inside. Carefully place the plate with the fish on top of the steamer basket,
4. Cover the pot with a lid and steam the fish for about 15 minutes, or until cooked through.,
5. In a small saucepan, heat the vegetable oil until hot. Remove the fish from the steamer and pour the hot oil over the ginger and scallions.,
6. Serve the fish hot with steamed rice and vegetables

name: Zhang Wei
bio: Zhang Wei is a Chinese chef who specializes in creating modern twists on traditional Chinese dishes. With 15 years of experience, he has developed a unique style that incorporates unexpected flavors and techniques while still honoring the classic flavors of Chinese cuisine.

recipes.name: Hunan-style Twice-Cooked Pork
recipes.method:
1. Heat a dry skillet over medium-high heat. Add Sichuan peppercorns and toast for 1-2 minutes, until fragrant. Remove from heat and grind into a fine powder.
2. In a small bowl, whisk together soy sauce, rice wine, cornstarch, and 1 tablespoon of the Sichuan peppercorn powder.
3. Heat vegetable oil in a large wok or skillet over high heat. Add pork and stir-fry until golden brown, about 5 minutes.
4. Remove pork from the wok and set aside. Add garlic, ginger, and green onions to the wok and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes.
5. Add bamboo shoots and red bell pepper to the wok and stir-fry for another 1-2 minutes.
6. Return the pork to the wok and pour in the soy sauce mixture. Stir-fry for 2-3 minutes, until the sauce has thickened and the pork is cooked through.
7. Serve hot, over cooked rice.

recipes.name: Sichuan-style Dan Dan Noodles
recipes.method:
1. Cook noodles according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
2. In a small bowl, whisk together Sichuan bean paste, soy sauce, rice vinegar, sugar, and sesame oil.
3. Heat vegetable oil in a wok or skillet over high heat. Add ground pork and stir-fry until browned, about 5 minutes.
4. Add garlic, ginger, and green onions to the wok and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes.
5. Pour in the sauce and stir-fry for another 1-2 minutes, until the sauce has thickened.
6. Serve

recipes.name: Kung Pao Chicken
ingredients: 2 boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cut into small pieces
recipes.method:
In a small bowl, mix together the cornstarch and soy sauce. Add the chicken pieces and toss to coat. Set aside.

In a separate bowl, whisk together the ingredients for the sauce.

Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat. Add the chicken and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes, until lightly browned.

Add the peanuts, red and green bell peppers, garlic, ginger, and dried chili peppers to the wok. Stir-fry for 2-3 more minutes, until the peppers are tender.

Pour in the sauce and stir to combine. Cook for an additional 1-2 minutes, until the sauce has thickened and the chicken is cooked through.

name: Wang Yibo
bio: Wang Yibo is a renowned chef with over 15 years of experience in Chinese cuisine. He is known for his innovative take on traditional dishes and his use of fresh, locally sourced ingredients. His recipes have been featured in top food publications around the world.

recipes.name: Cantonese Roast Duck
recipes.method:
1. Remove the innards from the duck and rinse it with cold water. Pat the duck dry and tie the legs together with kitchen twine.
2. In a small bowl, mix together honey, soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, salt, and Chinese five spice powder. Brush the mixture all over the duck.
3. In another small bowl, mix together maltose and boiling water until dissolved. Pour the mixture over the duck, making sure to coat it evenly.
4. Hang the duck up to dry for at least 6 hours, or overnight. If desired, brush the duck with red food coloring to give it a reddish hue.
5. Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Place the duck on a rack in a roasting pan and roast for 1 hour, or until the skin is crispy and the meat is cooked through.
6. Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or deep fryer over high heat. Carefully lower the duck into the oil and fry for 2-3 minutes, until the skin is golden brown and crispy. Remove from the oil and drain on paper towels.
7. Serve the duck hot, with steamed buns and your favorite dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Ma Po Tofu
ingredients: 1 tbsp fermented black beans, rinsed and drained
recipes.method:
1. Cut the tofu into small cubes and set aside.
2. In a small bowl, whisk together the chili bean paste, soy sauce, sugar, cornstarch, and chicken broth.
3. Heat vegetable oil in a wok or skillet over high heat. Add ground pork and stir-fry until browned, about 5 minutes.

recipes.name: Stir-Fried Bok Choy
ingredients: 1 pound bok choy, washed and trimmed
recipes.method:
Cut the bok choy into bite-sized pieces.

Heat the oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat.

Add the garlic and ginger and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.

Add the bok choy to the wok and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes until it starts to wilt.

In a small bowl, whisk together the soy sauce, oyster sauce, and water. Pour the sauce over the bok choy and stir-fry for an additional 1-2 minutes until the bok choy is tender and the sauce has thickened slightly.

Serve hot as a side dish.

Steamed Fish with Ginger and Scallions
